contextId.information: This hypothetical statement explains the reason why a person would not actually mend a garment in that way. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
Some languages might prefer, "if one did." This is an absurd situation that is not likely to actually happen. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

Jesus is describing a situation that could have happened in the past but did not. AT: "If someone had performed the miracles for the people of Tyre and Sidon that I performed for you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: If the mighty works which were done in you had been done in Tyre and Sidon

contextId.information: Jesus uses a hypothetical situation to teach the crowd. His point is that they should resolve the things they are able to resolve without involving the public courts. This can be restated to make it clear it might not happen. AT: "For if you were to go ... bit of money" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
contextId.quote: For when you go ... bit of money

contextId.information: This describes a situation that has not happened, but that the rich man would like to happen. AT: "if a person who has died would go to them" or "if someone who has died would go and warn them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
contextId.quote: if someone would go to them from the dead ones

contextId.information: Abraham states what would happen if the hypothetical situation occurred. It can be stated in active form. AT: "neither will a person who comes back from the dead be able to convince them" or "they will not believe even if a person comes back from the dead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: neither will they be persuaded if someone rises from the dead ones

contextId.information: This introduces a hypothetical situation. It means that this person's punishment for causing people to sin will be worse than if they had drowned in the sea. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
contextId.quote: It would be better for him if

contextId.information: This is a hypothetical future situation. It may never happen, but even if it does, Jesus tells people to forgive. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
contextId.quote: If he sins against you seven times

contextId.information: Jesus tells the disciples how to answer a question that has not yet been asked. However, people in the village will soon ask the question. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
contextId.quote: If any one asks you ... need of it

contextId.information: This is a hypothetical situation. Some translators may need to make it clear what Jesus was implying when he said this: "no, I will not rebuke them, for if these people were to be silent ... cry out" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: if these were silent ... cry out

contextId.information: This is the first of two hypothetical statements by Jesus. It was a way for Jesus to respond without giving them a reason to say that he was guilty of blasphemy. Your language may have a way of indicating that the action has not actually happened. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
contextId.quote: If I tell you, you will not believe
